title: fdrtd - federated secure computing

welcome_nutshell_1: Federated Secure Computing is an easy and conventient way to design, develop, and deploy secure distributed applications.
welcome_nutshell_2: the modern architecture is based on fast microservices and provides strong cryptopgraphy protocols both on-premises or in the cloud.
welcome_nutshell_3: fdrtd is a minimalistic reference implementation for commercial, scientific, and educational use.
welcome_nutshell_4: the free and open source software comes with a number of built-in features and can be tailored by plug&play extensions to your use case.
welcome_users_1: does your company or organization possess private, proprietary, or confidential data you can not, do not want to, or must not share with others?
welcome_users_2: do you realize this data would become much more meaningful and valuable if you could make it available for joint analytics with partners or even competitors?
welcome_users_3: with modern cryptography, secure distributed applications are a reality. several interested parties may cooperate and achieve joint results without data sharing, keeping their data in their custody at all times.
welcome_users_4a: discover <ilink>/users/usecases§use cases</ilink> from healthcare to autonomous driving.
welcome_users_4b: chart your <ilink>/users/journey§user journey</ilink> to secure distributed computing.

welcome_users_4e: approach us to help you <ilink>/users/start§get started</ilink>.

usescases_clinicalstudy_1: two or more university hospitals collect data on patients with a particular disease.
usescases_clinicalstudy_2: due to privacy regulation, the hospitals are not allowed to exchange any of their data.
usescases_clinicalstudy_3: with differential privacy (DP), hospitals may run joint evaluation on their aggregate data without sharing any of it.
usescases_adriving_1: analytics of peoples driving patterns can help manufacturers optimize their cars, and can help prevent traffic jams.
usescases_adriving_2: for privacy reasons, individual drivers would rather not share their travel history.
usescases_adriving_3: with privacy-preserving computation (PPC), cars can securely communicate peer-to-peer, and manufacturers can monitor fleet behaviour.
usescases_contacttracing_1: mobile apps can trace contacts and prevent the spread of COVID-19.
usescases_contacttracing_2: for privacy reasons, individuals would not want their contacts stored in a central database.
usescases_contacttracing_3: with decentralized privacy-preserving proximity tracing (DP3T), contracts can be traced in an anonymous fashion and exposed contacts still be notified.
usescases_spysatellites_1: spy satellites are fragile tin cans with a $300m price tag orbiting earth at a speed of about 15.000 mph.
usescases_spysatellites_2: collisions must be avoided at all costs, but orbital parameters cannot be revealed to other nations.
usescases_spysatellites_3: with secure multiparty computation (SMPC) even hostile nations can warn each other of collisions, without revealing orbital parameters.
usescases_supplychain_1: to improve resilience of their supply chains and identify systemic risk, manufacturers would like to have multi-level insights into their supplier's sourcing.
usescases_supplychain_2: suppliers, on the other hand, are reluctant to provide detailed information about their sourcing strategy.
usescases_supplychain_3: with zero-knowlegde proofs weak links in supply chains can be identified without distorting competitive advantages.
usescases_iot_1: smart sensors and smart devices can help run home appliances efficiently and reduce carbon footprint.
usescases_iot_2: while aggregate data may be useful to a housing community, individual tenants do not want IoT data to leave their appartment.
usescases_iot_3: with privacy-preserving computing (PPC), data may be aggregated without revealing anything about invidivual sensors.
usescases_benchmarking_1: companies would like to compare their key performance indicators (KPIs) to their competitors'.
usescases_benchmarking_2: alternatively, a company would like to provide feedback to their self-employed salesforce.
usescases_benchmarking_3: in both cases, players are reluctant to reveal their individual KPIs but would benefit from joint insights and analytics.
usescases_benchmarking_4: here, privacy-preserving computation forgo an expensive trusted 3rd party and can even create live dashboards.
usescases_yours_1: do you have any confidential data that would become more valuable if interconnected with other parties' data?
usescases_yours_2: what kind of analytics would you want to run on the data? and what security guarantees do you require?
usescases_yours_3: talk to us and let us find out if privacy-preserving computation might be the solution to your challenge.
journey_usecase_1: the user journey starts when institutions, businesses, or a group of individuals conceives an interesting use case (see some /users/usecase§examples).
journey_usecase_2: they identify some proprietary data the can not or must not share with each other, which would create additional insight if analysed in its entirety. the partners now want to realize the potential value.
journey_usecase_3: alternatively, if they have shared data so far, they now seek to design their digital collaboration in a more privacy-friendly way.
journey_usecase_4: in both cases, they need to protect their or their customers' or patients' data. they need to find a way to keep control, excert agency, and embody consent into their cooperation.

journey_ppc_3: these approaches are well-known to academic computer science and in the crypto community, but have not found their way into mainstream yet. there is some information to be found though:
journey_ppc_4a: <elink>https://www.accenture.com/us-en/insights/digital/maximize-collaboration-secure-data-sharing§Maximize collaboration through secure data sharing</elink>: a report by Accenture
journey_ppc_4b: <elink>http://publications.officialstatistics.org/handbooks/privacy-preserving-techniques-handbook/UN%20Handbook%20for%20Privacy-Preserving%20Techniques.pdf§UN Handbook on Privacy-Preserving Computation Techniques</elink>: a report by the Privacy Preserving Techniques Task Team of the United Nations
journey_ppc_4c: <elink>https://www.mpcalliance.org/§MPC alliance</elink>: an industry alliance of companies interested in secure multiparty computation
journey_consulting_1: companies interested in leveraging PPC for their use case should enlist the support of a consultant to help them navigate the unknown terrain.
journey_consulting_2: in a first iteration, the use case will be discussed. together, a first idea of what data to process in which way take shape. chances are the consultant will be able to identify additional value levers.
journey_consulting_3: the consultant will make a broad recommendation which technologies to look at more detail. a team is formed, a project is mandates, and a timeline is set. ideally, an end result is desribed in broad strokes.
journey_planning_1: the project team will now describe in greater detail:
journey_requirements1: part of the problem stems from the fact that academic research into privacy-preserving computation has led to universal one-size-fits-all solutions which tend to be large and complex.
journey_requirements2: actual user requirements on the other hand are actually quite reasonable and could be acieved with much less overhead and complexity.
journey_requirements3: further talking to decision makers and stakeholders quickly revealed: what was available was quite different from what was really required:
journey_requirements3a: they want to solve specific problems and did not care about universality
journey_requirements3b: their problems are typically quite simple in algorithmic terms
journey_requirements3c: they do not have any crypto experts and rely on generalist developers
journey_requirements3d: their data protection officers are sceptical about novel methods
journey_requirements3e: they need a precise standard that could be referenced in legal documents
journey_requirements3f: they need a prototyping approach that was up to speed with their CI/CD
journey_requirements3g: they want a framework that was as simple to operate and straightforward to service
journey_requirements3h: they want to collaborate with others who have very different systems
journey_requirements3i: they want to choose their own languages and development environments
journey_requirements3j: they need the new methods to be integrated step-by-step into legacy code
journey_approach1: <fdrtd>federated secure computing</fdrtd> is a technology designed along these requirements. it is a modern architecture based on fast and lean microservices to solve everyday problems in privacy-preserving computing.
journey_approach2: <fdrtd>fdrtd</fdrtd> is an open source reference implementation. the middleware lets users design distributed applications in a simple and easy way, and relegates all of the complex and difficult cryptography to the server or the cloud, where data protection is much easier to achieve, and computing power is abundant.
benefit_empowerment1: we want everyone, not only cryptography experts, to be able to design, develop, deploy and manage secure distributed applications.
benefit_empowerment1a: junior skills: for client-side development, very basic programming skills suffice. client-side developers do not deal with cryptography at all.
benefit_empowerment1b: choose your tools: use whatever programming language you prefer, choose your own tech stack, bring your own toolsets. they will be fine.
benefit_empowerment1c: for education: our simple solution is well suited for propaedeutic exploration, student projects, and citizen science. learn privacy by doing.
benefit_convenience1: our technology is not yet another privacy-preserving computation framework. rather, it is a convenient middleware to run existing frameworks in the simplest manner possible:
benefit_convenience1a: separation of concerns: a client-server architecture separates the business logic (client-side) from the computing intensive cryptography (server-side).
benefit_convenience1b: transparency: application developers interact through a transparent and minimal API. control flow and data flow in peer-to-peer protocols remain transparent.
benefit_convenience1c: efficiency: lean and fast microservices cater to actual computing needs, without the bloat of universal monolithic solutions.
benefit_convenience1d: ease of use: in a modern DevSecOps and CI/CD approach, designing, implementing, deploying and managing a solution becomes easy and straightforward.
benefit_compatibility1a: standardized: a free OpenAPI 3.0 standard defines the interface while remaining technology neutral and open for any protocol and 3rd party vendors.
benefit_compatibility1b: runs everywhere: our solution is not dependent on any tech stack, but runs everywhere, from a large cloud infrastructure to on-premises data centers, from workstations to laptops, from smartphones to IoT devices.
benefit_compatibility1c: easy to integrate: our solution may be implemented step by step, microservice by microservice, both greenfield or into existing legacy codebase.

news_2021-09-21_a: last Monday, we pitched our final project plan to Stifterverband (the German Donors' Association). we explained why we believe privacy-preserving computation should be available to all and how we plan to build a middleware that lowers barriers.
news_2021-09-21_b: today, Stifterverband announced that indeed Federated Secure Computing is one of ten projects to share one million Euros in funding for the next three years. they declared our project one of 'the ten best ideas to shape the German innovation, education, and science system'.
news_2021-09-21_c: the team is absolutely happy that our project can go on as planned. during the next three years we will make simple, affordable, and accessible privacy-preserving computation a reality for all institutions, companies, and individuals. thank you, Stifterverband, we promise to make you proud.
news_2021-05-31_a: during the past six month our team has received both financial support and invaluable counseling and mentorship by Stifterverband (the German Donors' Association) and its partners. their goal is to foster and promote ideas and initiatives which are expected to create substantial and lasting social benefit and to improve the German education and innovation system.
news_2021-05-31_b: we are immensely grateful to learn that the board has selected our project as one of the top 30 for the second phase of the program. during the next months we will concentrate on scalability, transferability, and sustainability of our proposition.
news_2021-05-31_c: if you want to help us create a convincing showcase, or if you are willing to contribute to the project, please contact the team. everyone is welcome.
news_2021-04-03: fdrtd is free and open source
news_2021-04-03_a: today, <fdrtd>fdrtd</fdrtd> has become free and open source. the first repositories have been published on GitHub under the MIT license.
news_2021-04-03_b: during the 'Wirkung hoch 100' mentorship, it has become clear that we may measure our success only by the systemic impact our solution creates. as a freely expandable open technology platform defined by an OpenAPI 3.0 standard, our solution is technically already very open. it naturally lends itself to become free and open source software.
news_2021-04-03_c: we believe the only way ahead in software development today is through co-creation. we invite everyone to take part in our adventure and become part of the team. together we can create not only a product, but rather a movement that changes how institutions, corporations, and individuals will deal in privacy and digital collaboration.
news_2021-03-12_a: today, <fdrtd>fdrtd</fdrtd> was demonstrated in front of a live audience of about 70 experts from the German healtcare informatics initiative.
news_2021-03-12_b: between two university hospitals in Munich and Dresden, a simple distributed calculation was performed ad hoc. the exercise was part of a hackathon and learning experience to build capabilities at the partner sites across Germany.
news_2021-03-12_c: UPDATE June 2021: in the meantime, different alpha versions have been successfully tested by six or more university hospitals.
news_2021-03-11_a: for the convenience of users who want to test <fdrtd>fdrtd</fdrtd>, there are public test servers available now. without the need to set up and run their own servers, scientists and developers may test our technology in minutes.
news_2021-03-11_b: the test servers will be regularly updated with the latest development build. they are completely open without authentication, so for security and privacy reasons, some functionality has been removed, and no personal data may be uploaded.
news_2021-03-11_c: our first batch of five public test servers is kindly provided to the scientific community by Leibniz Rechenzentrum (LRZ), one of the leading supercomputing facilities in Europe. additional servers for commercial enterprises will be provided on the infrastructure of Amazon Web Services.
news_2020-12-02_a: bytes for life GmbH is a spin-off of LMU Munich. it provides consulting in the area of technology transfer as well as software development with a focus on SaaS and cloud computing.
news_2020-12-02_b: the start-up will sponsor <fdrtd>fdrtd</fdrtd> and provide the necessary legal, financial, and operational framework such as team building, website hosting, human support, community events, and general oversight.
news_2020-11-09_a: 'Wirkung hoch 100' is a program by Stifterverband, the German Donor's Association. in its 100th year of operation, they decided to identify and support 100 ideas that have the potential to benefit the German education and innovation ecosystem.
news_2020-11-09_b: out of over 500 applications, <fdrtd>Federated Secure Computing</fdrtd> was selected to be one of the promoted projects. during the coming months we will receive funding and mentorship and will co-create with other teams what we believe is intelligent data protection made in Germany.
news_2020-11-09_c: our job is to make privacy preserving computation available to all by reducing barriers and creating awareness. we are thrilled to meet the other teams and even more motivated to push our development ahead.
news_2020-03-02: mobile and cloud boost secure distributed computing
news_2020-03-02_a: an early prototype of our technology demonstrates the benefits of a lean client-server architecture in the context of secure distributed computing.
news_2020-03-02_b: as a benchmark, we looked at a traditional secure multiparty computation solution we had devised earlier. the setup included two Intel Xeon servers, each 8 cores, 2.6 GHz, 128 GB RAM, and 1 Gb/s networking via fast internet backbone between university hospitals in Munich and Berlin. its devops required two systems administrators and one expert programmer for several weeks.
news_2020-03-02_c: by comparison, our early prototype ran on a Samsung Galaxy XCover 4, took 15 minutes to develop for a total of 9 lines of Python code, and executed a homomorphic encryption protocol via the public 4G mobile cell phone network, leveraging the server-side computing power of AWS Frankfurt.
news_2020-03-02_d: the result was exact to machine precision and took 4.5 seconds to compute, compared to 1,229 seconds of the original solution (speedup 10^2 ... 10^3).
pitch_beliefs1: we believe that it is only through collaboration, not isolation, that society, researchers, corporations, and individuals will make best use of their proprietary data and capture their full value.
pitch_beliefs2: we understand that privacy-preserving computation enables efficient collaboration while still preserving control, custody, trust, agency, consent, and privacy.
pitch_beliefs3: we envision transformative use cases for <fdrtd>federated secure computing</fdrtd> throughout industries and practises, whenever one must not, want not or can not share their data with partners and competitors.
pitch_beliefs4: we are convinced decentralised data storage and peer-to-peer data flow will make for faster, better, more resilient and ultimatively more sustainable and more democratic information infrastructure.
pitch_beliefs5: we challenge current barriers to entry and we do not accept that privacy-preserving computation should be difficult to develop, exclusive and expensive to own, or cumbersome to operate.
pitch_mission1: we empower everyone to engage in privacy-preserving computation and help them implement their use cases.
pitch_mission2: we advocated Federated Secure Computing, a free and open standard and a modern architecture to render secure computing easy and convenient.
pitch_mission3: we provide fdrtd, our free and open source reference implementation as a starting point for feature-rich solutions.
pitch_mission4: we foster an ecosystem and a community for users and developers to share and learn.
pitch_mission5: we help you design convincing show cases and support you in building secure applications.
